intro: Sidalcea campestris, commonly known as the field poppy, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the Fabaceae family, which is characterized by its legume fruits and often nitrogen-fixing capabilities. The plant typically grows in dry, open habitats such as grasslands and disturbed soils. It produces showy, pink to purple flowers that bloom in the summer months. Its leaves are alternate, ovate, and often have a fuzzy texture, contributing to its distinctive appearance.
